Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X94-J611-JB20-G4P2-00000-00Congressman Elijah Cummings Dies at 68; Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates; Marc Benioff of Salesforce is Being Interviewed About Digital Transformations; Chicago Teachers on Strike; Kellogg's Puts Six Brands in One box for "Spirit Day"; Los Angeles City Council Pushes $30.00 Hourly Minimum Wage for Uber and Lyft2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTArt Hogan, Marc Benioff, Marty Mosby, Dan MorganNEWSFinancial101702cb.231Congressman Elijah Cummings Dies at 68; Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates; Marc Benioff of Salesforce is Being Interviewed About Digital Transformations; Chicago Teachers on Strike; Kellogg's Puts Six Brands in One box for "Spirit Day"; Los Angeles City Council Pushes $30.00 Hourly Minimum Wage for Uber and LyftMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Cheryl Casone, Deirdre Bolton, Robert Wolf

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, October 17th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 on the button on the East Coast.

We have breaking news this morning. A draft deal has been reached on Brexit. U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he has reached a great new deal with E.U. negotiators. He's urging parliament to approve this deal this week. The E.U. commissioner, the president of the E.U. Jean-Claude Juncker also telling member nations to back this deal.

Markets are rallying on the news. Take a look -- poised for a higher opening this morning with the Dow Industrials off of the highs of the morning but nonetheless showing a gain of 94 points. S&P futures up 10. And Nasdaq futures up 29.

Markets finished down slightly yesterday after consumer spending came in lower than expected. There are fractional losses across the board yesterday.

Global markets this morning are following the draft deal on Brexit response. European indices higher across the board. FT 100 up 35 points, one-half of 1 percent. CAC 40 in Paris up 7 points. And the DAX index in Germany higher by 60 points, half of a percent.

In Asia overnight markets finished like this. And as you see, the best performer was Hong Kong. Hang Seng up two-thirds of a percent.

Also breaking news this morning. Maryland congressman and House Oversight Committee chairman Elijah Cummings has passed away, dead at 68 years old. He passed away overnight at John Hopkins Hospital from complications from long-standing health challenges.

The streaming wars this morning -- Netflix getting a boost from overseas subscribers. The company reported earnings last night. It did fall short on overall growth expectations but nonetheless, the stock is up 8 percent. The streaming giant downplaying the threat of other media powerhouses entering the streaming field.

Morgan Stanley earnings are due out later this morning. We will bring you the numbers and the analysis. Going into that print, the stock is up 2 percent.

Plus, teachers' strike in Chicago, a massive walkout on the nation's third largest school district impacting about 300,000 students. What the teachers are demanding this morning coming up.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business' Dagen McDowell; National Securities Corporation chief market strategist, Art Hogan; and Fox Business' Deirdre Bolton. A lot of news this morning -- guys.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: A lot.

BARTIROMO: Brexit.

BOLTON: It looks like at least both sides, right -- it seems like we have a deal. So we'll be looking for that. But futures moving higher on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. It takes a lot of the uncertainty out of the way.

BOLTON: Certainly.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I'll stifle until we get to this dude sitting to my right.

BARTIROMO: I believe we're talking about right now. Our top story this hour is we are remembering Elijah Cummings this morning.

The breaking news overnight is the Maryland Congressman and House Oversight Committee chairman has passed away. Shocking news for many of us.

His office released this statement. "At approximately 2:45 a.m. on Thursday morning, October 17th, 2019, Congressman Elijah e. Cummings of Maryland passed away at Johns Hopkins Hospital due to complications concerning long-standing health challenges. More details will be forthcoming."

Elijah Cummings represented Maryland's seventh congressional district since 1996. He was 68 years old. Our condolences go to his wife, Maya, and family.

Joining us right now is Fox News contributor, 32Advisers founder and CEO, and former economic adviser to President Obama -- Robert Wolf. Robert -- it's good to see you this morning.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you -- Maria. Hi, everyone.

BOLTON: Hi.

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Elijah Cummings.

WOLF: Listen, I know he's had an incredible number of issues with the current president but he was a great public servant. He was north of 20 -- I think 1996 is when he came into office. He obviously ran a lot of different committees. He currently chaired the oversight committee.

Listen, it has not been easy to be a politician in Baltimore the last decade with everything going on. And, you know, I think like all these different politicians, we may disagree or agree, but they're giving to our country to better it.

And I think it's a sad day. And he was a young man. I mean he was, I think you said 68.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It is. He was a good man.

WOLF: Yes.

BOLTON: That was the first thing we said when we sat down. God -- that's really young.

WOLF: Yes. I've had the honor of meeting him a few different times. And you know, he was always there for human rights and civil rights. And I think he always spoke truth to power, you know. And obviously in this polarizing environment, a lot of the good things that he's done over the years, everyone guy that goes to their corner but I think I think everyone is going to remember him as a great public servant.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. And our condolences to his family.

MCDOWELL: Donna Brazile on Twitter, she made a statement on his passing. And she ended it with rest in power.

WOLF: Yes.

BARTIROMO: She's terrific -- Donna.

MCDOWELL: Yes, she is.

WOLF: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We have a lot of breaking news this morning -- Robert, we want to get your take on.

Out of Europe, of course, we've got a draft deal that has been reached on Brexit. U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he's reached this quote- unquote, "great new deal" with E.U. negotiators and he's urging parliament to approve it this week.

Futures spiked on the news. You've got a rally in the Dow Industrials, up 83 points, coming off of the highs. You are the former chairman of UBS Americas -- your take on this?

WOLF: Yes. You know, when I was president of the investment bank we were in 27 countries. Our biggest business was in the E.U., right. Switzerland and Europe and everywhere from Turkey to everyone. I've had the ability to meet Erdogan and many other different leaders.

But U.K. was our prime hub. And I think that I was never for Brexit but I'm absolutely for a Brexit deal because once the public votes and they decide they're going to do this type of deal, they should proceed.

We're now three years into it. I hope this is a real deal. I hope -- listen, any -- we've been speaking about it for years. Any time we can take geopolitical risk out of the financial markets is a good day.

So this is a good day for the markets. I think it's a good day for all of the money managers around the globe because this is one thing we can now take off the table.

BOLTON: And for trade and for tech, right -- we're talking about how many American companies are based in Ireland and then, you know, with Ireland as part of the E.U. and Northern Ireland obviously in the U.K., I mean that was just going to create all kinds of hassle which is apparently the place that the compromise has finally been able to be made.

WOLF: Well, you gave me a big soft ball there because we've been speaking -- I always feel I'm to the right of the conservative party right now when it comes to fiscal responsibility and trade.

It would be great if the President and Boris Johnson now started talking about a bilateral trade. I was always for T-TIP, I've been for TPP -- the different trade areas but it would be great if we could have -- that will be --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: The President said as soon as the U.K. leaves, immediately they're going to do a deal, the U.K. --

WOLF: It will be a great thing.

BARTIROMO: -- and the U.S.

WOLF: Any time we can get our trading partners where we can figure out how to make one plus one equals three instead of two, is a good thing.

BOLTON: Yes, wind in the sails, right. And obviously we have a long relationship with the U.K.

WOLF: But I heard this morning when you guys announced it, which is great -- I think you were one of the first to announce the breaking news -- the question is we haven't seen any drafts of actually what they've agreed to. You know, we still have to get through parliament.

(CROSSTALKING)

BOLTON: There's a meeting later today.

WOLF: We still have to get through parliamentary --

BARTIROMO: We did get a good comment from the commissioner.

WOLF: Juncker -- right, which is great.

MCDOWELL: It's like small northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party has already come out and said that it's not going to endorse the agreement.

WOLF: With a lawsuit or something.

MCDOWELL: So there's already a wrench being put into it.

BOLTON: And Boris Johnson I think has a somewhat difficult relationship right now with the U.K. parliament. So we'll see how those conversations go.

BARTIROMO: Did that just come out? Maybe that's why markets off of their highs there -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: This is part of the reporting from the "Wall Street Journal".

BARTIROMO: Ok.

ART HOGAN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, NATIONAL SECURITIES CORP: Do you think there's been a lot of companies like UBS or -- that have already made a move out of London in terms of it being the financial hub or do you think people are waiting to see how this works out (ph).

WOLF: I mean there is no question that whenever you have a global business, you don't wait for the action to happen.

HOGAN: Right.

WOLF: You prepare years in advance. I remember for many, many volatile days Maria and I and Dagen used to always talk about Dodd-Frank. We didn't wait for Dodd-Frank to happen. We had to prepare years in advance.

Everyone has prepared for Brexit to happen, there's no question about it. Now they will have to look at what the new rules are.

I mean we really don't know how trade's going to be, going from open trade, open passport -- all this open environment to something that will be much more -- I don't want to say barriers of entry but there will be barriers of entry.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

The other news is that meeting yesterday at the White House. President Trump clashing with House lawmakers now over his Syria proposals. The President holding a tense bipartisan meeting yesterday at the White House after the House overwhelmingly voted to oppose the administration's withdrawal from Syria.

The meeting ended with Democrats walking out. President Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi both weighed in on this yesterday and had their own sides of the story. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Syria doesn't want Turkey to take its land. I can understand that. But what does that have to do with the United States of America? If they're fighting over Syria's land, are we supposed to fight a NATO member in order that Syria, who is not our friend, keeps their land? I don't think so.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: We just came from a most unsatisfactory meeting at the White House. As Speaker of the House I reported to the President that shortly before the meeting we had a vote in the Congress, 354-60 opposing his actions that he took in Syria.

Most importantly, asking the President what his plan was to fight ISIS now that he had disrupted what was going on in Syria. He couldn't handle it. He just couldn't handle it.

Two to one the Republicans voted to oppose what he was doing in Syria. But he kind of engaged a meltdown. And we were trying to get the answer, what is your clear plan that this resolution asks for, how we fight ISIS. It was very sad.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo travel to Turkey today for further talks. You heard Mike Pompeo, the Secretary of State with me yesterday talking about his goals for that trip. And he's basically wanting to ask Turkey for a complete cease fire. Your reaction?

WOLF: I mean this is -- listen, the environment has been incredibly toxic away from Pelosi and Trump. But in the last, you know, 72 hours, the only bipartisan issue that actually seems to be is that people are not happy with the President's decision with respect to the Kurds and Turkey.

You know, yesterday, when we were chatting, we found out that we're now having strategic alliances on this with Iran and Russia and Assad in Syria and all of a sudden our allies in Kurds have become in some ways our frenemies. And I think that -- I think that we have to kind of -- I would like to take a step back to see how we can get to a cease fire.

I mean no one likes what's going on.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLF: Yes. And I think that this kind of -- you know, we saw the letter that obviously that you guys broke yesterday with respect to Erdogan and Trump. And I think we're in a situation where people need to understand the President's decisions a lot better than via tweet. And it seems that Lindsey Graham and a lot of those who have been more hawkish, you know, seem to be obviously against what the President's decision is.

BARTIROMO: Here's the letter from President Trump to Erdogan saying let's work out a good deal. You don't want to be responsible for slaughtering thousands of people. And I don't want to be responsible for destroying the Turkish economy, and I will.

He ends it by saying don't be a tough guy, don't be a fool. I will call you later. President Trump.

Now, yesterday when Secretary of State Mike Pompeo joined me he put the blame of this increased chaos in Syria right now pointedly straight at Erdogan. Watch this.

WOLF: Right. Great interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: I've watched the world rally to push back against President Erdogan and the invasion that took place. We should never mistake who the actor is that has caused this disruption there. It wasn't the United States. It wasn't the European countries that were there in Syria alongside of us.

It was President Erdogan who is responsible for this instability.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: Maria -- that was a great interview. I do think that there's been some pushback on some of the comments he made to you, especially where he made the comment to you that Turkey would have fired upon the Kurds whether we were there or not there. I know that there's been some pushback on that statement, no disrespect to the secretary.

And so listen, I think that we're right now -- this situation is not going to stop. Yesterday a majority of the House including over 150 Republicans voted for -- over 100, I thought it was over 150 -- but voted for the idea that, you know, what the President decided to do was not -- it's now going to go to the Senate. I think that --

BARTIROMO: Voting no on his withdrawal of the troops from Syria.

WOLF: Correct.

BARTIROMO: Look, I understand that this is an issue that a lot of people agree that this is a dangerous situation to take the troops out. But I think the American people are sick and tired of all this fighting. I really do.

They have to start getting something done together.

MCDOWELL: If that's our national security, then so be it. But it was done rashly. It was done unexpectedly. Our own troops on the ground were not prepared for this.

We're having to bomb and basically fire on an installation that we had in that part of Syria to ensure that our enemies, like Russia, don't collect intelligence secrets on the ground, number one.

Number two, I'll add this. Why increase the military budget so dramatically if you're going to pull out? Number one, in terms of how much money we're spending as a nation and our $1 trillion annual budget deficits. Number two, don't you want the Republicans on your side when you're facing an impeachment inquiry by the Democrats in the House?

BARTIROMO: This was a campaign promise, take the troops home.

WOLF: Listen, I'm not a hawkish guy. I mean we've been speaking for a decade. The reason I backed Obama was because he wasn't for the war.

I don't have an issue with the President not being -- putting our men in harm's way. I mean we've all been supporters of Wounded Warriors forever and a lifetime.

I do think it's what Dagen said. It's about execution. It's about, you know, has this plan been executed with the right people around the table.

He's the President. He's the commander in chief. But the question I would have is on execution. And it seems that's where a lot of the pushback is happening.

MCDOWELL: Exactly. There are a thousand ISIS prisoners that could be -- could escape. There are 15,000 additional potential fighters on the ground there.

President Obama learned that you create a vacuum, you have to go back. So if the U.S. has to go back to prevent terror from arriving on U.S. shores, we have no allies because we just turned our backs on the Kurds.

(CROSSTALKING)

MCDOWELL: And turned our backs potentially on other allies because again, is this an individual in the White House that you can trust?

WOLF: Yes. It's a tough situation.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Robert -- thank you.

WOLF: Thanks for having me on.

Great interview with Barry Diller -- I have to say. I've been watching it the last past couple of days. It's fantastic.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Good to see you -- Robert. Thank you.

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Coming up the chaos in Hong Kong. Pro-democracy lawmakers protest as "South Park" grills Lebron James over China's comments. We've got it all when we come back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New chaos in Hong Kong's parliament.

Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Maria.

Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam was forced to suspend her annual policy address after she was heckled by opposition lawmakers. There's the video.

Security guards had to remove more than 10 people from that session. They demanded an inquiry into a brutal hammer attack on pro-democracy leader Jimmy Sham (ph) that happened yesterday. Sham currently is hospitalized with injuries from that attack.

Well, "South Park" taking on Lebron James for his comments about the NBA- China controversy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes. We do all have freedom of speech. But at times there are ramifications for the negative that can happen when you're not thinking about other than your own (INAUDIBLE) self.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes. Well, those are the exact words that James used when criticized -- he criticized Houston Rockets Daryl Morey for a pro Hong Kong tweet which set off that firestorm.

The NBA taken off the air in China. Many events surrounding exhibition games in China were canceled.

Finally there is there. Felicity Huffman's time behind bars may be cut a little bit short. The actress began her 14-day prison stay which stemmed, of course, from the college admissions scandal, yesterday. We told you that.

But TMZ is reporting now that she's going to serve 13 days because she already spent a few hours behind bars when she was arrested back in March. And we should add that a lot of folks call where she's at in California Club Fed, TVs, there might even be yoga from what we understand. I made that up.

BARTIROMO: She admitted it right off the bat. She's serving her time. I give her credit for being courageous on all of this.

BOLTON: Sure. That's right.

BARTIROMO: I just want to say talking about the Hong Kong-China situation, Cheryl, I just -- I think we have to put an underline into the comment that Xi Jinping made the other day. And I want to make sure our audience sees what Xi Jinping said about the Hong Kong protest.

And here's his quote. "Any further attempt to divide China will literally be crushed. Anyone attempting to split China in any part of the country will end up with crushed bones and crushed bodies and shattered bones."

BOLTON: In reference to Nepal? In reference to Hong Kong? In reference to anything?

BARTIROMO: He said it to the prime minister of Nepal. He's talking about anybody who protests.

BOLTON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Enough said. I just wanted to put that. I mean it just sort of shows you who you're dealing with. Crushed bodies, shattered bones.

We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Netflix posting mixed results last night with sluggish subscriber growth. The streaming giant posted a beat on earnings though and a miss on new domestic subscribers. The company added over half a million subscribers -- new subscribers in the U.S. amid an estimated 800,000.

Joining us right now is Synovus Trust portfolio manager Dan Morgan. And Dan -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks for joining us.

DANIEL MORGAN, TRUST PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SYNOVUS: Hi -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the Netflix quarter?

MORGAN: Well, it's like you said -- Maria. I mean they beat on that third quarter but then the guidance going into the fourth quarter was really shy of the Street. They were looking for, what -- 9.23 million subscribers. They came in with 7.6 million.

So that kind of led to a bit of, you know, concerns about new subscriber growth going forward with competition coming in as we talked about before, with Apple TV, you've got DisneyHulu and all these other Disney Plus. So how is that going to work in going forward in terms of adding new subscribers when they kind of fell a little bit short of estimates on the fourth quarter?

HOGAN: Hey Dan -- are we getting to the point where we're getting close to saturation at least domestically for streaming? We've got -- feels like we've got a dozen new products coming at us in the short run and Netflix's growth over the last three quarters hasn't shown any domestic growth, it's all been international.

Do you think domestically we're pretty well saturated in the streaming business? Is that only going to get worse with new competition coming in?

MORGAN: You're exactly right. I mean if you look at their overall quarter, let's say they just did 6.8 million in terms of subscribers. They were short of 7 aggregate but only a small portion was domestic. I think it was 6.3 was international which was a little above the estimates of 6.2 million.

But yes, you get to this point where the real opportunity is in the international space and yet we have all these big domestic names coming on, battling it out with content. So to me, the real challenge for Netflix going forward is can they continue to add content internationally and continue to grow and also monetize their existing base?

We talk about that with Spotify and Facebook. But, you know, they have 160 million people using their service. And let's face it, the growth is going to start to slow down. So how do you monetize and increase the amount of revenue per user opposed to having to just focus on like you're saying adding new people domestically which is tough.

BOLTON: Dan -- Deirdre here. Netflix is the, let's say poorest performing stock of the FANGS. Do you buy at this level?

MORGAN: We have a small position in that -- not a huge position for us. I think there's going to continue to be challenges going forward. We know that Disney Plus is coming out here in November, we've got Apple TV -- $4.99, $6.99 a month.

So you're going to continue to have more headline news working against Netflix because of worries about competition. So I think it makes it a little bit more challenging for them as being one of the big FANG stocks to continue to have the performance they've had like, you know, three or four years ago.

BOLTON: Yes. And I should have said year-to-date.

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry. What do you think about IBM. And just reminding that they closed the Red Hat acquisition only a week before the last earnings. So it's the first quarter that they're reporting their numbers in IBM's quarter.

It did post a miss on revenue. The stock is down 5 percent right now. What would you do with IBM?

MORGAN: You're right -- Maria. And, you know, this quarter they did, what, $370 million in revenue on their Cloud and cognitive segment which is where the Red Hat numbers came in. That was up 6.5 percent.

But all their other segments, their services and everything else is pretty much flat to down. Fifth consecutive quarter of negative revenue growth. So it's a very challenging stock because it's probably going to be out until approximately 2021 before we really see the full amount coming on with Red Hat in terms of accretion towards earnings.

So I think at this time, Maria, it's still going to be what it's always been. It's a dividend stock. It's a value play. It's going to take a year or two for this thing to really be perked up from the Red Hat acquisition. I think investors are just going to have to be patient and kind of reap that big dividend.

BARTIROMO: The third quarter Cloud revenue was $5 billion and it was 14 percent cloud revenue growth in the quarter. Is that do you think are the growth story right now, one of the growth stories in tech, Cloud?

HOGAN: Oh, 100 percent. The problem with IBM is they took too long to make that pivot, right. So this acquisition as you mentioned, $34 billion which they probably paid too much for, for Red Hat, is moving them in the right direction.

But remember, they have to get that integrated. They have to find the synergies. They probably paid too much for Red Hat. And while they're doing that, they're not buying back their shares. So they suspended their share buyback. And that's affecting their earnings as well.

I mean it took a long time to get in the game. They're in the game now but it's going to take a while to --

BOLTON: Can they catch up to Amazon and Microsoft, for example, for Cloud?

HOGAN: Yes, they can. The problem is while they're doing it, Dan just pointed this out I think this is correct. Their legacy business is dying a slow death. It's a melting ice cube. So they, you know, it's going to be a slow ride -- they will get there but it's not 2020, it's 2021.

BARTIROMO: Hard to see growth the bigger you get. Hard to generate growth the way that you see in some of these other smaller names.

HOGAN: Yes. It's also important to have made a pivot earlier in the game. So you look at a Microsoft, which did this years ago. You need to get to the Cloud. You look at a Cisco which actually, you know, turned into a recurring revenue story much faster than people realized and they ditched their legacy business a lot quicker.

IBM didn't do that. They hung on too long. And now they're chasing -- they probably overpaid for Red Hat.

BOLTON: The big thing, right. Can companies -- can big companies innovate? That was the whole Clay Christensen (ph) saying it long story short. The answer is usually no.

HOGAN: You usually don't.

BARTIROMO: Apple seems to be doing it, actually.

Dan -- real quick before you go, would you buy these two stocks here?

MORGAN: I think you could have kind of a wait and see on Netflix just because of the competition element that we talked about before.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: We own a pretty good sizable position of IBM. I think you could look at it as a dividend play. I think they've got a 4 to 5 percent dividend. It's way up there.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: So you kind of get paid to let it happen, right, over the next couple of years.

BARTIROMO: All right, Dan. Thank you so much. Good to see you, Dan Morgan joining us, Synovus.

MORGAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Bank earnings also in focus this morning. We are awaiting Morgan Stanley right now; it's the third quarter earnings report. We are looking at the stock trade up going into the numbers.

Joining us right now is Vining Sparks Bank and Equity strategist -- Strategies Director, Marty Mosby. Marty, it's always good to see you. Thanks for being here. What's your expectation on Morgan Stanley?

MARTY MOSBY, DIRECTOR, VINING SPARKS BANK AND EQUITY STRATEGIES: Well, we think that the -- you know, what we're going to see is in line with what the market thinks, around $1.15 is the expectation. We are seeing a little bit of revenue pressure because of what they have from their private wealth management and the -- you know, the net interest income that they generate. So a little bit of pressure with lower interest rates that will make them be down sequentially.

But overall, Morgan Stanley's a favorable stock for us as we move into next year. They kind of trough out when rates begin to stabilize.

HOGAN: You know, when you look at some of the bank earnings so far this week, I think we've seen some pretty surprising but my biggest surprise, I love to get your thoughts on this, is loan demand seems to be growing much bigger than -- much larger than our expectations, both in the corporate level and the consumer level. Do you think that's going to -- going to be a theme or we're going to continue to hear when we get down to the regionals, because it's certainly the major J.P. Morgan city bank in America all talked about strong loan demand.

BARTIROMO: Let me interrupt you, Morgan Stanley is out. We got to get right to Lauren Simonetti. The stock is up three percent. Let's get the numbers, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, the news is good. This is the last of the big six banks to report and Morgan Stanley reporting earnings per share of $1.27 versus the estimate of $1.11 so that was a nice, healthy beat there. And they also beat when it came to revenue. Little over $10 billion in the quarter. The Street was expecting $9.6 billion.

So once again, the banking sector has not felt the sting of lower interest rates just yet. This is a welcome increase in the share price because when you look at Morgan Stanley which is up eight percent year-to-date but it is trailing its peers by a pretty wide margin. And the KBW Banking Index (INAUDIBLE) is up 17 percent. So double beat right here for Morgan Stanley, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Hogan, we've been waiting on this numbers. Sorry to interrupt you there. You want to give us a reaction here that we got a better than expected top and bottom line before we get back to Marty on his analysis.

HOGAN: Yes, across the board. And it's interesting; Morgan Stanley is a much steadier business now because they've really transitioned (INAUDIBLE) over to financial advice, right? So they're no longer that sort of going after Goldman Sachs' business, investment banking, they're still a player but their largest portion of their business is the financial advisor business and I think that's a very good sign to see that kind of growth.

BOLTON: Yes, financial sector earnings, sorry, have been actually pretty bright, right?

MCDOWELL: And gold -- but Goldman Sachs is the softest of the bunch, wasn't it? In terms of the earnings report because it doesn't have the stability of a Morgan Stanley business and it doesn't have the deposits of a J.P. Morgan, but who does?

HOGAN: And they had a bunch of deals that went south for them. So their calendar has been difficult this year and that's the problem. When you -- when you live in that market, you live or die by the calendar and Goldman Sachs certainly didn't.

MCDOWELL: It's got that Apple card (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Marty, what do you think? The stock is 3-3/4 percent right now. It's moving and moving fast. Your reaction to this quarter?

MOSBY: Well, actually, this extra nickel of earnings that we're seeing is likely coming from what we had in the fixed income area. We saw a couple of positive beats there. So they're getting the benefit of that. Also what they were seeing was, you know, the IPO market would have been kind of a head wind this quarter. So there must be some other investment banking business that they're being able to pull through.

So all in all, this is a good stabilization for them, instead of seeing that downturn of about five percent were talking about, this is about even with what we were at earlier this year.

So, and what we're getting in the overall theme of banks is a sustaining of earnings power and returns and the valuations really don't reflect that. So if we can see credits stay relatively low and the cost of credit low, we can see that the banks can manage through the interest rate pressures with, you know, growing the balance sheets like you were talking about earlier with strong loan growth. Then I think that we can see these things start to work towards the end of this year and going into next year.

BOLTON: Marty, Deirdre here, you mentioned the investment banking business. How is it that more and more companies are doing these direct listings? So Spotify was sort of the first one to do it, taking out the middlemen in a way that are the investment bankers. Do you see this happening more? What does that mean to the investment banking business?

MOSBY: Well, again, it's an evolution that we're seeing in the financial markets. But we're seeing that also with the regulation on traditional banking. There's more things happening outside of that. So what that does mean is that the banks' balance sheets and the banks' business mix are really a lot less risky and a lot less kind of leveraged to the froth that can't come into the market, the extra business and the extra deals that are getting done are happening kind of outside of those traditional channels.

So that is an incremental thing that's happening in relation to regulation and things like that that have been much more strict on the traditional business models.

HOGAN: Marty, we're seeing some great reports so far. But it's been the bulls' brackets in the -- in the major money center banks. Does this translate down to the regional banks when we start to hear from them over the course of the next couple of weeks?

MOSBY: Yes, we saw some good news yesterday from U.S. Bancorp and PNC as well as BB&T and SunTrust. So we think the super-regional banks actually if you look year over year are still growing about six to seven percent. Where the money center banks are kind of holding relatively, you know, flat, given the head winds that they've had with capital markets and some of the investment banking.

So we do believe because they have extra liquidity, they're getting active, they're increasing that loan growth, that loan demand is there. That's incremental earnings that really haven't been counted on and at those credit costs which we believe we have a credit cycle monitor forecasts that for the next year, the credit cost should stay relatively stable. That's a positive for the group that again isn't calculated into valuations right now.

BARTIROMO: All right, Marty, great to see you. Thank you so much for your analysis. Appreciate it.

MOSBY: Nice talking to you.

BARTIROMO: Marty Mosby joining us there.

Quick break and then Marc Benioff sounds off, the Salesforce founder and co-CEO weighs in on regulating big tech, the future of capitalism and the cloud. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A top technology leader declaring, quote, capitalism is dead, that is just one of the blockbuster headlines from my sit-down with the co-CEO of Salesforce, Marc Benioff also said to me that Facebook is the new cigarettes. We covered a range of issues from artificial intelligence to homelessness. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: How would you characterize the macro environment and I know that people are worried about CapEx spending?

MARC BENIOFF, FOUNDER AND CO-CEO, SALESFORCE: Well, I was in Munich yesterday, I was in London on Monday and here I am in New York today. And you know our customers are all still very aggressively investing in their digital transformations.

Those transformations begin and end with the customer. That's why we're involved in those conversations. We continue to see a tremendous work in digital transformation worldwide as all companies transform themselves to connect with their customers in new ways and I think the environment remains very good.

That said, you know that I'm a trustee at the World Economic Forum and Angel Gurria is the head of the OECD, I just saw him in Paris, and he has - - basically taken his global growth rate from four percent to three percent because of what's happening with this trade situation.

So he said, and I agree with him, if we resolve the trade situation, global growth will resume its climb. So that would be very exciting.

BARTIROMO: When there's uncertainty around, I think business managers the first thing they do is they sit on capital. But when you're talking about digital transformation, this is a must spend, isn't it?

BENIOFF: It's a must spend. You are 100 -- you are right. Because, look, every company and every customer is trying to build a 360-degree view of their customer because today if you don't have a direct connection with your customer then you're not really competitive in the world and it doesn't matter if you're in retail or banking or healthcare or you pick your industry, Maria, everyone is transforming and connecting with their customers in new ways and bringing the -- bringing new ways to connect companies and customers together.

BARTIROMO: I guess the market got spooked yesterday and a little today about Workday and Workday CEO comments about the environment. Europe is having a really hard time generating any growth. Can you give us a sense of what you're seeing in Europe? It's the same thing in Europe or do you see Europe a little slower than the United States?

BENIOFF: Europe has been healthy for us. We've had 30 percent growth there the last quarter. It's been good for us and like I said, I was there yesterday; I was meeting with the very largest companies in Germany and in the U.K. And, look, they're investing. Those are the conversations that we're having and everybody just wants to have this trade issue resolved.

BARTIROMO: Is the growth story at Salesforce from data analytics going forward? I mean, I'm really getting to this recent acquisition that you made. I know that your -- it's very early on so you're not -- you're not going to say a lot about it but Tableau have been talked about in terms of another big growth story for Salesforce. Where do you see the growth within the company in the next five, 10 years?

BENIOFF: Well, you know, we've had a fantastic shareholder return and if you bought our stock in 2004, it's been a 3400 percent return. We forecast it that we'll go from, you know, guidance $16.9 billion or approximately $17 billion this year to $28 billion within three years, fiscal year 23.

We see really expanded growth but that growth is all anchored on one thing, which is this digital transformation phenomenon and the focus on customer which is the only word that we do at Salesforce which is help companies connect with their customers.

BARTIROMO: But do you worry about the trade fight going on and China getting ahead of us in some of these really important technologies like A.I.?

BENIOFF: I don't view it like that. I think actually that we're quite competitive with all countries and all industries. And I could make the case on why that is true. But what I will tell you is there is a lot of transformation happening. This is the fourth industrial revolution. You do have A.I., you do have robotics. You have the biosciences.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes.

BENIOFF: You know, there's many things happening around the world and in all industries and I've never seen so much transformation and change and innovation.

BARTIROMO: You've got your Dreamforce conference coming up next month. This is your opportunity to put on this big show, tell the world what's coming, what's coming at Salesforce. Can you give us a hint in terms of the push into new areas?

BENIOFF: well, you've just talked about it. You know, it's all about A.I. and we call it Einstein. You know, Einstein, artificial intelligence, and just to connect the dots, you know, one of the things that we just showed is we have Einstein and it's running on a drone and it's over the ocean right now in Santa Barbara.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

BENIOFF: And it's able to classify and I just -- and we just put this on my Twitter feed that it saw a great white shark heading towards a school of kids in a surf camp in Santa Barbara. And it was able to call the park and then say, get the kids out of the water and you can see the shark and you can see the A.I. saying oh, there's a -- there's a shark there.

Now, just five years ago, that was not possible. OK. But today and you know this already because of the special you just did on A.I., it is possible and we can do a lot of things and that's an example of improving the world through A.I.

Because you know, technology is never good or bad. It's what you do with the technology that makes a difference. So we have to keep that mind as we start to think about values and our businesses.

BARTIROMO: You make a really good point because we are right now in this discussion about how technology will change as a result of perhaps more regulation.

So we've got some social media companies that are stronger and more powerful than we've ever imagined. What are you expecting? And is it bifurcated in terms of tech where we might see regulation or not see regulation? What do you expect in terms of what's coming from Washington, what should be changed with regard to regulation on big tech?

BENIOFF: Well, you know I just wrote about this in my book, which is that -- and we were there together, actually, in Davos in January, you know, 2018 and I said, you know, Facebook is the new cigarette. It's addictive. It's bad for you. They want your kids. Now they're posting political ads with incorrect information. They are passing your information to 50,000 other companies. You don't even know what's happening.

And now they're buying assets like WhatsApp and like Instagram and co- mingling all that data and if you saw that Netflix special called the big hack, they're creating market segments called the persuadable and shifting elections based on that data. Well, that's not good, that nobody wants that.

We want a society based on trust and truth. That's so important. And this is something we all need to be committed to. We have to focus on trust as our highest value.

BARTIROMO: You write a book, it's called Trailblazer: The Power of Business as the Greatest Platform for Change. Why did you write this book?

BENIOFF: Capitalism as we know it is dead. You know, the businesses need and we all need a new capitalism. And that is a capitalism that is more fair, more equitable and more sustainable. And that's a capitalism that includes all stakeholders, not just shareholders. This concept that the business of business is business is over.

What are stakeholders? It's your employees, your customers, your partners. By the way, I'm from San Francisco. It's about our homeless.

BARTIROMO: I've got to talk to you about that.

BENIOFF: Let's do it. And also, public schools and the planet. I mean, I'm the CEO of a big company now, not just a start-up like when I met you. We have 45,000 employees, $130 billion. You know in market cap.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations, Marc.

BENIOFF: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What an incredible growth.

BENIOFF: Isn't it cool?

BARTIROMO: And you're using that to give back.

BENIOFF: Well, you know, what's funny Maria is that you know, we've had a great shareholder return. You know, like I said, 3500 percent since we went public. But we've also had a great stakeholder return, $300 million in grants, four million hours of volunteerism. We have also been able to run 40,000 non-profits and NGOs for free on our service. We're a net zero company which means we don't have any net new carbon emissions. And we'll be fully renewable by 2025. That's our stakeholder return.

All companies can report not just their shareholder results like you cover so well here but your stakeholder results too. We do. We publish a stakeholder report. The SEC has the opportunity and I read about this in the New York Times this week, to say to companies, tell us about your stakeholders and what you're doing for them.

BARTIROMO: You know, I want to -- I want to push back on this for a minute. Because this has been in your blood, in your DNA, this whole notion of stakeholders. So you're maybe different in this category. But when I first saw the Business Roundtable decision, I said to myself, wait a minute, does that mean that employees and the communities you operate in weren't important beforehand? I mean, I thought it was a little bit of P.R.

And I also said, well; wait a second, what about shareholders, what about capitalism? Who's going to stand there and defend capitalism?

BENIOFF: This is a new capitalism. It's where shareholders are as important as stakeholders and it's coming from within the companies. It's coming from within. People who are working inside companies today to say, I'm not just here to make money. I'm here to improve the state of the world. And I know you feel that way. It's why you are here in this network and left the other network.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

BENIOFF: You're here because this is your platform and you use your platform to improve the world. I know that because I've watched you for decades.

But I'm also using my platform to improve the state of the world.

BARTIROMO: What are you thinking about the homelessness issues in California right now? Any ideas in terms of --

BENIOFF: Oh, I have a lot of ideas. That's why a year ago I spent $7 million to work to pass a tax to actually tax Salesforce which is called Proposition C in San Francisco to create more homeless services because we badly need extremely low income housing and social services. It's been proven by medical studies, by clinical studies, and we're just not doing enough.

And so, 62 percent of the voters actually passed this and it's in the courts right now, but we need more services. And this concept of extremely low income housing, well, as I told you, I was just in Europe, if you go to France, you know, they have a minister of low income housing. They call it social housing. And they plan it inside their communities. We just don't do that. We have not planned these big cities like you just mentioned to really know -- everybody's not going to be able to afford the gorgeous apartment or house that you and I live in. We have to be able to create housing for everyone and that is a way and a critical way to help eliminate homelessness. The key to homelessness is housing.

BARTIROMO: Marc, thank you so much for your leadership.

BENIOFF: Great to see you. Thank you, Maria. Great to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. The book is Trailblazer, pick it up. Marc Benioff, is the founder of Salesforce.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We're going to have reaction to that interview from Congressman Andy Barr coming up.

But first, Chicago teachers are on strike. The standoff affecting nearly 400,000 public school students.

Then, Kellogg's new morning crunch makes breakfast a little more interesting. Wait until you see this one. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Breaking news, Maryland Democratic Party Chair and Elijah Cummings wife Maya Rockeymoore Cummings just issued a statement on the death of her husband.

She says this; Congressman Cummings was an honorable man who proudly served his district and the nation with dignity, integrity, compassion and humility. He worked until his last breath because he believed our democracy was the highest and best expression of our collective humanity and that our nation's diversity was our promise, not our problem.

It's been an honor to walk by his side on this incredible journey. I loved him deeply and will miss him dearly, Maya Cummings.

Meanwhile, thousands of Chicago parents are scrambling this morning. Cheryl Casone tell us why now, Cheryl.

CASONE: Well, a lot going on in Chicago this morning, Maria. Chicago public school teachers have gone on strike. They sent those teachers in the city closing schools for that job action. The Teachers Union announcing last night its 25,000 members would not be in classrooms today. The city and the Union have been trying to hammer out a contract for months. You are looking right now at live pictures coming out of Chicago. Again, all public schools in Chicago closed today and the strike is ongoing.

Well, lawmakers out in Los Angeles are pushing a $30.00 minimum wage for Uber and Lyft drivers. The city council already approving the study of how the law would actually work under and half the money would go to wages. The other half would be used for expenses like gasoline.

And Kellogg's is getting into the spirit. They're creating a new cereal, it's called All Together. It's going to support the activist group GLAAD's anti-bullying Spirit Day. So the cereal is a mix of -- get this everybody, Frosted Flakes, Fruit Loops, Rice Krispies, Frosted Mini Wheats, Raisin Bran, Corn Flakes. And it's all in one box. It's only available at Kellogg's New York City cafe. So we'll all be going down there shortly. Sounds like a lot of fun, sugar and calories altogether.

BARTIROMO: Yes, a lot of sugar there. Thank you, Cheryl.

Coming up, Trump versus House Democrats, the president holding a reportedly contentious meeting yesterday at the White House. Speaker Nancy Pelosi was there, she stormed out. Details next hour, with one House lawmaker on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, back in a minute.

The Brexit deal pushing Futures higher this morning, markets are higher by about 89 points, we're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages this morning. NASDAQ up 36, S&P up 11 points.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XBK-5T11-DYTH-G1XS-00000-00CONGRESSMAN JESS "CHUY" GARCA INTRODUCES BILL TO KEEP BIG TECH COMPANIES OUT OF FINANCIAL SECTOR2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisCONGRESSMAN JESS "CHUY" GARCA INTRODUCES BILL TO KEEP BIG TECH COMPANIES OUT OF FINANCIAL SECTORStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, D.C.

The following information was released by the office of Illinois Rep. Jesus Garcia:

Today Congressman Jess "Chuy" Garca (IL-04) questioned Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and introduced H.R. 4813, the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would block Facebook from developing its controversial Libra Project. The bill prohibits Facebook and other big tech companies from developing digital currencies.

"At today's Financial Services Committee hearing, I introduced the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would prevent Facebook and other tech giants from developing digital currencies or assets like Libra. Big tech companies like Facebook are entering the financial services market at an alarming rate. Given the enormous access that tech giants like Facebook have to people's data and their ability to manipulate markets through their size and power, the prospect of them operating a bank or currency is troubling.

"Left unregulated, Facebook is another 'too-big-to-fail institution' like those that caused the 2008 financial meltdown. Not only will Facebook use their monopoly on private data to manipulate markets, consumers will be exposed to immense financial risks without government protections for their money or investments.

"Mr. Zuckerberg stated that Facebook should not be regulated like a bank or by the SEC, despite growing expert legal agreement about how to protect consumers. Zuckerberg basically said that he doesn't want anyone looking over his shoulder or reviewing his company's books. Given Facebook's track record of evading criminal liability, abusing private data, and manipulating markets with their monopolistic power, regulators should be considering how to break up Facebook, not greenlighting a new, dangerous project like Libra.

"We have a responsibility to protect the American public and every day consumers. To do so, we must hold Big Tech giants like Facebook accountable and keep them from entering the currency market. My Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act does just that."

In the coming weeks, Rep. Garcia will be introducing additional legislation that further strengthens the separation between banking and commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Rep. Raul M. Grijalva, D-Ariz. (7th CD), issued the following news release:

Today Congressman Jesus "Chuy" Garcia (IL-04) questioned Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and introduced H.R. 4813, the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would block Facebook from developing its controversial Libra Project. The bill prohibits Facebook and other big tech companies from developing digital currencies.

"At today's Financial Services Committee hearing, I introduced the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would prevent Facebook and other tech giants from developing digital currencies or assets like Libra. Big tech companies like Facebook are entering the financial services market at an alarming rate. Given the enormous access that tech giants like Facebook have to people's data and their ability to manipulate markets through their size and power, the prospect of them operating a bank or currency is troubling.

"Left unregulated, Facebook is another 'too-big-to-fail institution' like those that caused the 2008 financial meltdown. Not only will Facebook use their monopoly on private data to manipulate markets, consumers will be exposed to immense financial risks without government protections for their money or investments.

"Mr. Zuckerberg stated that Facebook should not be regulated like a bank or by the SEC, despite growing expert legal agreement about how to protect consumers. Zuckerberg basically said that he doesn't want anyone looking over his shoulder or reviewing his company's books. Given Facebook's track record of evading criminal liability, abusing private data, and manipulating markets with their monopolistic power, regulators should be considering how to break up Facebook, not greenlighting a new, dangerous project like Libra.

"We have a responsibility to protect the American public and every day consumers. To do so, we must hold Big Tech giants like Facebook accountable and keep them from entering the currency market. My Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act does just that."

In the coming weeks, Rep. Garcia will be introducing additional legislation that further strengthens the separation between banking and commerce. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com

Jesus Chuy Garcia (D-IL) News Release2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:02ZLexisNexisU.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES DOCUMENTSCongressman Jesus "Chuy" Garcia Introduces Bill to Keep Big Tech Companies Out of Financial SectorRep. Jesus Chuy Garcia (D-IL) News Release

Washington, D.C. - Today Congressman Jesus "Chuy" Garcia (IL-04) questioned Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and introduced H.R. 4813, the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would block Facebook from developing its controversial Libra Project. The bill prohibits Facebook and other big tech companies from developing digital currencies.

"At today's Financial Services Committee hearing, I introduced the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which would prevent Facebook and other tech giants from developing digital currencies or assets like Libra. Big tech companies like Facebook are entering the financial services market at an alarming rate. Given the enormous access that tech giants like Facebook have to people's data and their ability to manipulate markets through their size and power, the prospect of them operating a bank or currency is troubling.

"Left unregulated, Facebook is another 'too-big-to-fail institution' like those that caused the 2008 financial meltdown. Not only will Facebook use their monopoly on private data to manipulate markets, consumers will be exposed to immense financial risks without government protections for their money or investments.

"Mr. Zuckerberg stated that Facebook should not be regulated like a bank or by the SEC, despite growing expert legal agreement about how to protect consumers. Zuckerberg basically said that he doesn't want anyone looking over his shoulder or reviewing his company's books. Given Facebook's track record of evading criminal liability, abusing private data, and manipulating markets with their monopolistic power, regulators should be considering how to break up Facebook, not greenlighting a new, dangerous project like Libra.

"We have a responsibility to protect the American public and every day consumers. To do so, we must hold Big Tech giants like Facebook accountable and keep them from entering the currency market. My Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act does just that."

In the coming weeks, Rep. Garcia will be introducing additional legislation that further strengthens the separation between banking and commerce.

urn:contentItem:5X39-NXV1-DY0W-43JX-00000-00Congressman vows to pursue regulation of big tech with open mind2019-06-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisCongressman vows to pursue regulation of big tech with open mindTOM SSCHOENBERGSUSAN DECKERBloomberg NewsBillings, Mont.FULL TEXT

WASHINGTON — Legislation and more regulation of technology companies such as Alphabet Inc.’s Google and Facebook Inc. is possible, but lawmakers are approaching scrutiny with an open mind, the federal lawmaker leading an antitrust investigation of the industry said.

“This is an investigation to collect the best data and best information,” Representative David Cicilline, the Rhode Island Democrat who leads the House Antitrust, Commercial & Administrative Law Subcommittee, said on “Fox News Sunday.”

Cicilline’s committee is set to hold its first hearing on the dominance of Big Tech on Tuesday, part of a wider probe of the industry that the lawmaker said may lead to legislation. The goal, he said, is to “bring more competition to the space.”

The companies provide platforms for consumers and gather information that is then used by advertising companies, political parties and other groups. It’s become controversial, particularly after private information from Facebook was mined by a British political consultancy tied to Donald Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign.

“The data that’s collected is used to generate revenue, so they’re not really free,” Cicilline said.

Here’s a guide to the U.S. antitrust case against Big Tech:

Consumer advocates and a newspaper trade group are scheduled to testify on the effect of digital platforms on news media organizations, possible anti-competitive conduct of “dominant firms,” and whether current laws and enforcement policies are adequate, a person familiar with the hearing has said.

The U.S. government is ramping up its antitrust scrutiny of Big Tech on several fronts. The Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission recently signaled that formal investigations may be forthcoming by divvying up antitrust oversight for Apple Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google.

Cicilline has also said recently that concentration in the digital markets industry has resulted in anti-competitive behavior, breaches of privacy and consumer’s losing control of their own data. The antitrust subcommittee will seek company records and gather testimony from corporate officials through depositions and hearings, Cicilline told Bloomberg Television in an interview last week.

WARREN’S PLAN

In the past few years, there’s been calls from some lawmakers to at least rein in, if not break up, technology companies that are seen by some as having become too big and powerful in many ways. Senator Elizabeth Warren has made perhaps the most detailed case for breaking up and regulating the four companies, but the Massachusetts Democrat, a 2020 presidential hopeful, isn’t alone in her aggressive views on the industry.

Tech companies have been preparing for scrutiny for a while, hiring lawyers and lobbyists and publicly making their case. History may be on their side: corporate breakups are a significant, and rare, undertaking for the U.S. government. The last major breakup of a monopoly was AT&T in 1982. Microsoft was ordered split up by a federal judge in 2000 after the Justice Department sued the software company in 1998, a decision that was reversed on appeal.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V6N-2H51-JBJH-345M-00000-00Congress May Soon Impose New Regulations On Facebook2019-01-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisAll Things Considered08:00 PM ESTTim MakSarah MillerRon WydenMark WarnerCongress May Soon Impose New Regulations On Facebook

ARI SHAPIRO: Is Facebook ripe for disruption in 2019? That's a question we're asking in this week's All Tech Considered.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ARI SHAPIRO: Generally, Washington has taken a hands-off approach to tech platforms, not wanting to slow down an economic powerhouse. After multiple scandals involving Facebook, though, this attitude seems to be changing. Conservative lawmakers have criticized the social media giant for what they view as censorship of their end of the political spectrum. And now, as NPR's Tim Mak reports, progressives are becoming critics, too, for different reasons.

TIM MAK: Power - this one word sums up the rise in concerns on the left about tech behemoth Facebook.

SARAH MILLER: The fundamental problem with Facebook is its power - its market power, its power over the discourse, its power over the way we think and consume information.

TIM MAK: That's Sarah Miller. She's a co-chair of Freedom from Facebook, a coalition of progressive groups opposed to the social media company.

SARAH MILLER: Because of its control over information, it is really one of the world's most dangerous monopolies.

TIM MAK: Over the past year, Facebook endured a scandal over Cambridge Analytica's use of personal data and has seen its stock price plummet over privacy concerns. Facebook has been accused by Congress of being used to spread Russian disinformation. And it has also been accused by U.N. experts of being used to incite violence in Myanmar. Here's Miller again.

SARAH MILLER: We don't want to live in a country where Mark Zuckerberg decides who lives or who dies.

TIM MAK: As criticism has mounted, Facebook hired an opposition research firm that attempted to discredit Freedom from Facebook by linking the group to George Soros. By the way, Soros' foundation have supported NPR in the past. This tactic of linking Freedom from Facebook to Soros, who is Jewish, struck some of Facebook's critics as anti-Semitic. So Facebook severed ties with the research firm. The social network did not comment on the story by deadline, but Facebook has said in the past that it is open to privacy regulation. So following these scandals, lawmakers on the left are increasingly turning their attention to regulating Facebook.

RON WYDEN: On issue after issue, Facebook has not told the truth to their customers.

TIM MAK: That Senator Ron Wyden, the Democrat from Oregon who has been a leading progressive voice on issues from consumer protection to killer drones to the big banks. He is championing new data privacy legislation and believes that the left is increasingly passionate about the need for reforms to Facebook and other big tech firms.

RON WYDEN: This is an issue where our side that wants some accountability and some dramatic reforms to put the consumer in the driver's seat - I think we're picking up grassroots support continually.

TIM MAK: Wyden told NPR that Facebook is in an endless cycle in which it lies to consumers, then apologizes, then undertakes what Wyden called meaningless reforms.

RON WYDEN: We're going to have to say, if these CEOs lie to their customers and lie to the federal government, there's going to have to be a real deterrent. That means significant fines and the possibility they will serve jail time.

TIM MAK: Wyden's frustration is shared by Senator Mark Warner, who is the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, has been investigating Facebook's role in Russian interference with the U.S. political system.

MARK WARNER: This is not going to be an area where we can rely upon the goodwill or self-policing of these platforms.

TIM MAK: Sarah Miller, who, as you might remember, leads the progressive anti-Facebook coalition, is proposing one solution.

SARAH MILLER: We have kind of all come together around a set of solutions that includes restructuring the company, so breaking up Facebook, allowing competition to kind of flourish again in the social media space.

TIM MAK: This thinking has at least one ideological ally on the right. Conservative Senator Ted Cruz has suggested he supports using anti-trust laws to break up big tech firms. With Republicans concerned about censorship, Democrats concerned about privacy and no end in sight for the scandals, Facebook finds itself in the unenviable position of having to weather a rare bipartisan storm. The question now is what action Congress will take in the year ahead. Tim Mak, NPR News, Washington.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TB3-4YM1-JCB8-W14Y-00000-00Congress must come together to save the internet2018-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisBopinion/commentaryPg. 4Congress must come together to save the internetPATRICIA FORD ;

In a zero-attention-span society, even the most important issues slip out of mind when they drop from the headlines or get bumped from cable news. It's happening right now with net neutrality -- a critical issue that affects everyone who uses the internet that seems to have fallen off the face of the earth.

In a zero-attention-span society, even the most important issues slip out of mind when they drop from the headlines or get bumped from cable news. It's happening right now with net neutrality - a critical issue that affects everyone who uses the internet yet seems to have fallen off the face of the earth.

Last December, the Trump Administration repealed President Obama's net neutrality rules, setting off a firestorm of media attention and - if only briefly - focusing national attention on the need for clear rules ensuring that no internet company can block unpopular websites or unaffiliated services or otherwise discriminate online.

There was then a brief effort to revive the rules through a highly partisan longshot approach using the Congressional Review Act (CRA) that made some headway in the Senate but was always, as its sponsors knew too well, dead on arrival in the House of Representatives.

While well intentioned, it's no surprise this CRA tactic could not gain a foothold. It fetishized an anachronistic "public utility" approach to net neutrality that many regarded as gratuitous overkill for a largely unregulated internet and a buzzkill for new investment. It also oddly paid worship to administrative regulations that change with every new administration rather than a permanent law. Even if it had succeeded, the Trump FCC could have altered them again. It's kind of like that game of infinite regression.

As much as we should celebrate consensus - and there seems to be widespread agreement on net neutrality now - legislation still seems to be the obvious coda. Legislation is a kind of "trust but verify" insurance policy against a future provider that may want to, say, favor its new streaming service over those of, say, Netflix or Disney. But there are other reasons too - interfering with internet traffic to increase profits is not just a salon-dinner theoretical conversation about future misbehavior by internet providers, it's a current day way-of-life for the Internet's new gilded monopolies like Facebook and Google.

Those companies that collect and profile our data and decide what we can see and where we can go online pose a greater risk of censorship and manipulation of our data than anyone. Washington's big thinkers in technology have come to the party late - after months of front page stories of how these companies facilitate election interference, hate, and civic chaos and marketplace tyranny that is strip-mining our news, retail and creative industries.

Many of these leaders are now demanding that net neutrality cover these Big Tech monopolies as well as internet providers - something only a new law from Congress can effectively ensure. It would seem obvious to anyone watching the disintegration of the internet that there is a crisis too big to corporate promises or overworked regulators.

Net neutrality for all goes to the basic ability of citizens to connect and communicate, to find meaningful information, to organize and participate in the political process in a fair and open way.

On a bipartisan basis, Congressional inaction conjures images of Nero fiddling while the internet burns. There is little disagreement about net neutrality widely applied and little disagreement about reining in abuses that led to the Russia scandal, among others. It's up to party leadership on both sides to prove, contrary to growing populist sentiment in both camps, that they are not made up of decaying old politicians but rather modern problem solvers up to the task of protecting the most important communications medium of our time.

There is a huge middle ground available here and a real opportunity for the kind of common sense problem solving Americans routinely tell pollsters they want. It'll only happen if we drop the political jawboning and get on with the peoples' business.

Patricia Ford is a former executive vice president of the Service Employees International Union.

FILE - In this Thursday, Dec. 7, 2017, file photo, demonstrators rally in support of net neutrality outside a Verizon store in New York. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer, File)

Mary Altaffer

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S9J-50T1-DYTN-R3TY-00000-00Congress must work on crafting internet reform bill2018-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:03ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A7Congress must work on crafting internet reform bill

The collective palls of scandal (and alleged scandal), impasse and hyper-partisanship in the nation's capital may have many voters thinking of the Beltway as a dysfunctional wasteland. But in reality, much of the machinery of government is, in fact, going full throttle trying to create jobs, spur growth, and protect consumers. But this good news is routinely omitted from the daily news cycle.

A prime example of good government action is taking place at my old agency, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), where Chairman Ajit Pai is focused on increased transparency and positive changes to outdated rules. Most recently, following a new openness that makes the text of every proposed major rule public at least three weeks before any final vote, the FCC quickly acted to streamline internet regulation and clear away obsolete, depression area rules that threatened to turn the internet superhighway into a muddy dirt road.

Pai has his critics, of course. Some are concerned that eliminating these antiquated "utility" rules will undermine internet openness and "net neutrality," the principle that internet providers cannot speed up or slow down access to certain websites and applications.

While lawyers can legitimately argue about the merits of a Title I versus a Title II regulatory framework, there is general agreement that net neutrality and internet freedom has always been the norm and will continue to be the norm in the US. All internet providers have committed to such openness and the Federal Trade Commission is readily able to police those commitments.

Moreover, there is a major bipartisan effort underway in Congress to enact an even farther-reaching and permanent net neutrality law, which will truly bring the issue to a close. This movement is being given booster fuel by rising concerns over abuse of privacy following the recent Facebook drama. The time is ripe for comprehensive reform to protect consumers online, bring real accountability and privacy protections to the big tech platforms as well as internet providers, and make net neutrality the permanent law of the land.

Unfortunately, the excessive partisanship and cynicism in Washington could cause us to miss this chance. Much of the energy needed for this reform is currently being diverted into a misguided attack on the Pai deregulation effort through a procedural tool called a "Congressional Review Act" resolution. This CRA calls for a show vote one that puts Congress on record disapproving of Chairman Pai's actions. This approach only returns the question to the uncertain netherworld of political impasse, which continues to feed concerns that Washington is incapable of implementing new privacy rules and a permanent net neutrality statute.

Frustration with this kind of gamesmanship has led many states to look for workarounds to protect net neutrality and privacy on their own, an understandable but ultimately doomed effort. There is only one internet, and it requires consistent steady federal rules to operate effectively. A patchwork of different requirements and regulations will leave too many gaps in place to genuinely protect online privacy, and it will introduce new friction to the system and slow down the internet while undermining new deployment that could close the digital divide. That's a big step backwards for consumers.

Instead of short-sighted state-based contortions, we should continue to urge Congress to roll up its sleeves and get to work on a comprehensive internet bill. Our leaders in both parties have the same goals and vision as most Americans a free and open internet available to every American, access to affordable fixed and mobile high-speed broadband in every home, school, library and business, and a competitive, jobs-producing communications marketplace with expanding investment and innovation. And no one has a monopoly on the best ideas for protecting consumers or serving the public interest.

We need all hands on deck and all ideas on the table to solve this problem. Congress should follow the practical common sense example set by Chairman Pai with his forthright and open leadership. He is showing that even in an age of gridlock and partisanship to the extreme Washington can still get things done. That means putting aside the flawed CRA and looking past inadequate state-based efforts to pass a real, substantive, permanent law on comprehensive net neutrality.

Kathleen Abernathy is special counsel at Wilkinson Barker Knauer LLP. She served as a commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission from 2001 to 2005.

Your Turn

Kathleen Abernathy

Guest columnist

FCC Chairman Ajit Pai is showing that even amid D.C. gridlock and partisanship, things can still get things done, writes Kathleen Abernathy.

Jacquelyn Martin/AP
